Alcol e tradizione. Studio esplorativo sull’evoluzione degli stili del bere nelle zone di produzione e in quelle di consumo [Fondazione CRC et al.] La ricerca è stata ideata e coordinata da Franca Beccaria e dal prof. Fabrizio Faggiano dell'Università del Piemonte Orientale. Prendendo in esame i dati dell’ISTAT, quelli del sistema di sorveglianza PASSI e i dati sulle dimissioni ospedaliere, gli epidemiologi, coordinati da Fabrizio Faggiano, hanno messo a confronto i dati di mortalità e malattia legati al consumo di bevande alcoliche delle “aree vitate” e di quelle “non vitate” del Piemonte, evidenziando una situazione più positiva proprio laddove esiste una forte tradizione vitivinicola. Lo studio qualitativo, coordinato da Franca Beccaria, consiste in 81 interviste individuali rivolte a donne e uomini di tre diverse generazioni (18-25 anni, 45-52 anni, 70-77 anni) e realizzate in Provincia di Cuneo in un campione di comuni suddivisi tra le Langhe e il Roero e la pianura, dove il vino viene consumato ma non prodotto. Lo studio è stato pubblicato da Carocci nel volume dal titolo “La rivoluzione del bere. L’alcol come esperienza culturale”, a cura di Franca Beccaria.

Ricerca “Alcol e generazioni. Cambiamenti di stile e stili in cambiamento” [Finanziamento: Osservatorio Permanente sui Giovani e l’Alcool] Responsabile della ricerca italiana e parte del gruppo italo-finlandese. Abstract Nel rapporto tra individui e bevande alcoliche, l’Italia e la Finlandia hanno costituito due mondi un tempo molto lontani. Possiamo dire che hanno rappresentato, in maniera paradigmatica, le due culture del bere: quella del Sud Europa (la cultura “bagnata”) e quella del Nord Europa (la cultura “asciutta”). Culture diverse per i momenti e i modi del bere, per le bevande consumate, per i significati attribuiti all’alcol, per l’intensità e gli orientamenti delle politiche di controllo. Da qualche anno tuttavia le distanze si sono ridotte. Sotto il profilo delle abitudini, delle bevande, delle quantità consumate. Anzi, si è assistito ad un effetto paradossale: nei consumi pro-capite la Finlandia – dove si sono intensificate, negli anni, le iniziative tese a ridurre la disponibilità delle bevande alcoliche e a scoraggiare i consumi – ha superato l’Italia, dove notoriamente le politiche di controllo sono quasi inesistenti. E proprio la curiosità per questo paradosso è all’origine di un progetto di ricerca comparata tra i due Paesi, promosso, per l’Italia, dall’Osservatorio sui Giovani e l’Alcol, e, per la Finlandia, dal National Institute for Health and Welfare. Sono stati messi a confronto i dati quantitativi e le tendenze dei consumi nei due Paesi, i cambiamenti delle abitudini e degli stili del bere (con un’attenzione particolare ai significati attribuiti all’alcol nelle succedersi delle generazioni), gli orientamenti delle norme e delle politiche in materia. La ricerca ha previsto la realizzazione di 16 focus group condotti in Italia e in Finlandia, suddivisi in 4 generazioni. Hanno partecipato allo studio 190 persone. Il confronto appare di grande interesse per quanti si occupano di alcol, di educazione ad un suo uso responsabile, di prevenzione dell’abuso, di gestione delle conseguenze e dei problemi alcol-correlati. E, più in generale, per chi è chiamato a programmare le politiche e i servizi. Pubblicazioni: Beccaria F. (2010) (a cura di), Alcol e generazioni. Cambiamenti di stile e stili in cambiamento. Abstract: The European Alcohol Policy Research Alliance Abstract: Taking into account the European research gap for effective policy-making, AMPHORA has created the European Alcohol Policy Research Alliance. Internationally renowned experts are engaged in the analysis of scarcely explored or non-explored noteworthy areas of alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harm, shared out in 9 interdependent work packages. These areas include existing interventions and policies, socio-cultural determinants, advertisement, taxes, pricing, availability, access, early diagnosis and treatment, drinking environments and surrogate and illegal products. WP4 Objectives 1. To quantify the volume of exposure of alcohol advertisements on television to young people within selected European countries; 2. To examine the impact of individual exposure to alcohol marketing, and the impact of the overall volume of alcohol marketing in the country on the drinking behaviour of 12-15 year olds in selected European countries over a three year period; and 3. To examine the impact of alcohol expectancies and liking of alcohol marketing on the relation between alcohol marketing exposure and drinking behaviour of 12-15 year olds in selected European countries over a three year period. Intimate partner violence and use of alcohol. Qualitative comparative study. [National Institute for Health and Welfare - Helsinki; Academy of Finland] Principal investigator: Maria Holmila, National Institute for Health and Welfare, Helsinki (FI). Italian CO-PI: Franca Beccaria Abstract: The focus of the study "Intimate partner violence and use of alcohol.Qualitative comparative study" looks at the associations of alcohol use with intimate violence between men and women. Earlier studies have shown that intimate partner violence is linked with heavy use of alcohol and drugs. The connection is complicated and influenced by cultural attitudes and perceptions of drinking as well as gender relations. As existing quantitative studies leave many questions unanswered, the research will use qualitative data to create in-depth understaning of this phenomena. The study involves researchers from 11 different countries world-wide, majority of them representing low- or middle-income countries. Comparable data are collected by focus-group interviews among young adult men and women from the general population, and among care-giving professionals (nurses, physicians, social workers), who deal with problems of alcohol-related violence. The interviews will use a pre-planned agenda to discuss cultural understandings of intimate violence and its links to alcohol consumption, attitudes toward such violence, and beliefs and attitudes about how to prevent such violence. The study also looks at the consequencies of violence in different cultures and contexts. Data coding and analysis use qualitative software to analyze recorded focus group discussions. The proposed research is innovative and significant in its development of comparable cross-cultural qualitative data on alcohol and violence, enhancing understaning of how drinking and drug use contributes to intimate partner violence in different cultural environments. Such knowledge is important for developing better local and national strategies to prevent intimate partner violence and the various harms it creates both for the victims and their families. The project is important also for building a greater capacity for badly needed research on alcohol problems and its prevention in communities of lower- and middle-income countries. The proposed study has grown out of the scientific cooperation in the international study "Gender, Alcohol and Culture: An international study (GENACIS). Pubblicazioni: Holmila, M., Beccaria, Ibanga, A., Graham, K., Hettige, S., Magri, R., Munné M., Plant M., Rolando S., Tumwesigye N. (2014). Gender, alcohol and intimate partner violence: Qualitative comparative study. Drugs: Education, Prevention & Policy, 21(5):398-407.

Alcohol & images (ricerca sulle percezioni dell’alcol tra i giovani italiani e finlandesi) [ERAB Foundation: www.erab.org] Principal investigator: prof. Franco Prina, Università di Torino; co-applicant: Franca Beccaria. Franca Beccaria ha coordinato la ricerca sul campo realizzata da ricercatori junior. Abstract: The research provides in-depth knowledge through comparative qualitative studies about the mechanisms through which environments of childhood growth and development are translated into alcohol use, which in turn has an impact on children’s and young people health and welfare. The Italian study focus on: - adolescent drinking scenes in low and middle-class neighbourhoods, involving children between 12 to 16 years recruited in focus groups from different schools. There will be 20 groups altogether, with 5-7 participants each. - comparisons of images of adolescent drinking between parents and teachers recruited from schools in working-class and in middle-class neighbourhoods. 8 groups of parents and 3 groups of teachers (5 to 7 participants per group) will be organized. A pilot study on adolescent has been already done in Torino, with 10 focus group that have involved 59 young people aged 15 in collaboration with the Finnish research group. “Binge drinking”: significati e pratiche di consumo tra i giovani italiani. Un’indagine esplorativa [Osservatorio Permanente sui Giovani e l’Alcool] (2013-14). Responsabile della ricerca: Franca Beccaria. Abstract: Il termine binge drinking viene sempre più impiegato dalla comunità scientifica per misurare il bere eccessivo e dai media per descrivere il bere giovanile e una presunta crescente propensione dei giovani ad ubricarsi. Le statistiche mostrano però discrepanze e sollevano interrogativi cui si è cercato di rispondere attraverso una ricerca qualitativa mixed-metods basata su 134 interviste individuali e un forum on-line rivolti a giovani (15-24 anni). I risultati mostrano che la categoria binge drinking include stili di consumo molto differenti che non necessariamente orientati all’ubriachezza e che non è corretto parlare di “normalizzazione” del bere eccessivo in quanto permane una concezione negativa dell’ubriachezza anche tra i giovani. Pubblicazioni: Beccaria, F., Rolando, S. (2015). Binge drinking e ubriachezza. Problemi di definizione culturale. Psicobiettivo. 3:77-93. Beccaria F., Petrilli E., Rolando S. (2015), Binge drinking vs. drunkenness. The questionable threshold of excess for young Italians. Journal of Youth Studies, 18(7):823-838.

Gambling policy in European welfare regimes [Università di Helsinki, Faculty of Social Sciences]. Franca Beccaria has coordinated the Italian team, with the aim of doing the following studies. Sub study 1 – Justifications Objective: analysing major changes since 1980 A review of the national existing literature (including reports, white papers and grey literature) and a systematic analysis of all the laws and the parliamentary debates dealing with gambling since 1980. Besides, 2-4 individual interviews addressed to key-informants have be realised focusing on recent major changes in the gambling market and regulation, the fiscal arguments, and the EU influence. Sub study 2 - Evaluations Objective: understanding the fiscal dependencies of service providers on sources of gambling revenues. A review of the national existing reports and literature plus some individual interviews with representatives of beneficiaries of gambling revenues (e.g. services providers, NGOs, sport associations,…). Sub study 3 – problem profiles Objective: evaluating the impact of gambling supply on problems. To collect and analyse the existing population national surveys on gambling and investigate the availability of studies/data on outpatients and helpline calls.

Drinking, gender differences and social change. The gendered dynamics of Swedish drinking situations from a comparative perspective (FORTE) [Center for Social Research on Alcohol and Drugs, Stockholm University-SW] (2014-17). Data analysis and articles writings based on previous Italian, Swedish and Finnish data collection. The research questions: (1) What kinds of situational drinking identities have become customary from the 1960s onwards in Sweden, Finland and Italy? What kind of changes have women’s and men’s relations to main drinking situations undergone in the recent decades? In what way are these gendered and situational styles of drinking related to other categories of difference, such as age, education and ethnicity? (Focus group interviews; textual and visual material) (2) How do the informal norms of drinking (regulating the pleasures and harms of drinking) vary by situation and how have they changed over time? How have the informal norms of drinking been gendered, generational, educational and ethnic and what kinds of changes have taken place in them in the four decades since? (Focus group interviews) The data is analyzed by applying tools of content analysis, semiotic sociology and visual semiotics. Franca Beccaria ha coordinato l'analisi dei dati italiani e partecipato alla stesura di alcuni articoli

Understanding the dynamics and consequences of young adult substance use pathways. A Longitudinal And Momentary Analysis in the European nightclub scene [Call: ERANID, www.eranid.eu] (2016-18) Partner Italiano, responsabile ricerca online. Abstract The nightlife scene is synonymous with drug use and its economy has surged in the last decade. Meanwhile, an unprecedented number of New Psychoactive Substances has emerged. The potency of ecstasy pills has doubled, alongside a rise in health incidents. Previous studies have failed to capture the dynamic aspects of nightlife drug use, both in the short-term (before, during, and after the club) and the longer-term (changes over time). A pan-European understanding of these issues is necessary to implement optimal policy decisions for nightlife licensing, drug control, and harm reduction. The proposed study combines state of the art interdisciplinary techniques (momentary or ‘real time’, long-term, subjective, biological) and comparison across countries, to thoroughly characterise drug use pathways (short- and longer-term) and their consequences.
